document_title: Fatty liver: Causes, symptoms and prevention
subsection_content:
The main cause of the disease is drinking a lot of alcohol or alcoholic drinks for a long time. In addition, people with the following health conditions are also at higher risk of getting the disease:(2)
Overweight, obesity; High blood cholesterol levels; People with hepatitis; Type 2 diabetes; Risk factors; Polycystic ovary syndrome; Sleep apnea; Impaired thyroid function (hypothyroidism); Impaired pituitary function (hypopituitarism); Elderly
Some tests reflect liver cell inflammation and cirrhosis
To know whether there is hepatitis or not, doctors often rely on a number of indicators: ALT (SGPT), AST (SGOT), ALP, GGT and < 35 U/L for men and < 25U/l for women. In a healthy state, these indicators will fluctuate within the range:
ALT (Alanine Transaminase): < 35 U/L for men and < 25U/l for women; AST (Aspartate Transaminase): < 35 U/L for men and < 25U/l for women; ALP (alkaline phosphorus – APL): 64 – 306 U/L; GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase): in men < 55 U/L, in women < 38 U/L; Total bilirubin: 3.4 – 17.1 μmol/L.; Direct bilirubin: 0 – 7 μmol/L; Indirect bilirubin: 1 – 17 μmol/L
When this test increases, it reflects inflammation in the liver. However, if the test is normal, it cannot rule out whether there is secret inflammation in the liver or not.
If fatty liver is suspected to progress to cirrhosis, the patient will be prescribed additional liver function tests such as prothrombin ratio, albumin...
